title: Military Lied About Vulnerable Huawei Equipment
text:
Military officials knew of the vulnerability to hacking of Huawei and other Chinese equipment they use as early as last year, it was revealed Monday.

Faced with concerns over such weaknesses, the military had previously remained silent about vulnerabilities and claimed it was using no Huawei equipment anyway.

But according to a document obtained by the Chosun Ilbo, military authorities last November sent out official notifications to troops warning against an expected escalation in cyber security threat from outside the country including North Korea.

"Due to the growing use of the Internet of Things, 5G, drones and other fourth industrial revolution-related technologies, the military is facing an increasing possibility of data theft using new hacking techniques," the memo warns.

The military specifically pointed out that "there are concerns over backdoor programs and hacking involving Chinese-made IoT products and 5G network equipment."

Backdoors are installed by unscrupulous manufacturers to permit clandestine access to supposedly safe application programs or computer networks. The U.S., as part of its trade war against China, claims Huawei has installed such backdoors and warned allies not to use its equipment. But so far only America's own Apple has been found out.

Asked about the memo on Monday, the Defense Ministry said, "Rather than referring to specific Chinese-made equipment, we were simply voicing general concerns over IoT and 5G network equipment made in China."

In other words, it claims not to have had Huawei specifically in mind. But the military apparently uses Huawei as well as other Chinese-made communication equipment on dozens of bases, although officials deny this.

The ministry also issued a warning to troops of suspicions that North Korea was behind 45 percent of hacking attempts targeting it.
description: Military Lied About Vulnerable Huawei Equipment
